headline: The Lead with Jake Tapper
subHeadline: Alex Murdaugh Being Cross-Examined At His Murder Trial. Aired 4-5p ET

utterances.speaker: CREIGHTON WATERS, PROSECUTOR
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: ALEX MURDAUGH, MURDER DEFENDANT
utterances.sentences: When he passed away, I had his badge and that was one -- at some point in time you were asking somebody about two badges. That was the other badge.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: I got you. You said you did five criminal jury trials as a prosecutor, correct?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Assisted in those or was doing them, yes, sir. I believe I was the lead lawyer in one of them. I helped my dad in the other four.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Still a part of preparing the case?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Yes, sir.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Still a part of gathering the evidence and putting it together at trial?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: In a criminal case we didn't do much gathering of evidence. We took what law enforcement had gathered, but --

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Putting it together for the criminal trial, correct?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Yes, sir.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Presented evidence in court?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Yes, sir.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Giving jury argument?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I did the closing argument in one of them, yes, sir.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Did you have any cases you prosecuted that went short of a jury trial, either plead out or were dismissed for some reason?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: You know, I'm sure that at some point between 1998 and 2021 that I took some plea, but, as we sit here today, I can't specifically remember that. I don't ever remember working a case for trial that didn't go to trial. I'm sure at some point in time I was involved in some level on a guilty plea, or guilty pleas.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: And you would agree with me that the civil system and the criminal system have a lot of differences, correct?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: A lot of differences and a lot of similarities.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: A lot of similarities, that's where I was going next. Fundamentally, it's about analyzing the evidence, preparing for trial, presenting that case and making an argument to the jury, correct?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: That's a big part of it.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Okay. And would you agree with me that as cases go on, or as you are preparing for trial, that you analyze the evidence that's been gathered by law enforcement and present the evidence that supports your case, correct? That's just part of it?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Presenting evidence that you deem favorable for your position?

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: That you analyze the evidence and you put in the evidence that supports your case, would you agree with that?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Yes, that's part of what you do.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Same thing in a civil case. As you go on you have evidence, you analyze the evidence and some evidence makes the cut and some does not, is that fair to say?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: As far as what you're trying -- I think we agree on that.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: It's a simple agree.

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I'm not exactly sure what your question is, but I think I understand it.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: I'm just asking you that as a lawyer, as you've been since 1994, is that right?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: That is correct.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: It's a simple question, you analyze the evidence that's been gathered, whether civil or criminal, and present that in court, is that correct?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Yes, that's part of what you do.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: It's an ongoing process as you prepare for a case, is that correct?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: An ongoing process as you prepare -- in criminal court or civil court?

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Either one.

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Well, there's a distinction because in civil court, you have deadlines and you aren't allowed to gather evidence during a trial or a week before trial or -- for instance, if this was a civil trial and we found that OnStar data during the third or fourth week of trial, you wouldn't be able to use it because you're past deadlines. In a criminal case, you are able to use it.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Would you agree that none of that was the fault of anyone on this side of the table, that GM initially responded they had nothing and then responded all of a sudden they did?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I don't have an opinion. It's certainly not anything I'm intending to convey.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: You talked to the jury a lot of about that, but you know nothing about that particular part? Is that what you're telling us? You talked to the jury a lot about the GM data, but you're telling me you're unaware that GM initially responded to law enforcement's timely request and said they didn't have that, but during the course of the trial, all of a sudden, it came up and said, you know, we found something and that's the reason it arrived late? You're saying you don't know anything about that after talking to the jury about that?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I don't know a single thing about that. I know y'all represented that to the court and I don't have any reason to doubt it. I don't --

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: And you agree that's generally consistent with the telemetry data that the FBI did, correct, the OnStar data?

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: All right. You don't think they're consistent with one another? Is that what you're telling this jury?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: No, I'm not telling the jury anything about that. I'm saying -- do I think they're consistent? I think they're telling -- I think the OnStar data tells one -- gives you one set of information and the telemetry data gives you another set of information.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: You don't think they're consistent? I mean, you talked about it to this jury. I think we're struggling on what's a fairly simple point, don't you agree?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Mr. Waters, I'm just trying to answer your question. I'm not trying to be difficult. I just -- my understanding of what you're referring to as the telemetry data is when a car goes into park and drive, and that sort of thing. Is that what you're referring to?

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: And the GPS information is telling you where a vehicle is in a certain path.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Correct.

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: And what direction they're going. I think they're just -- they're two different types of information.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: The question is, were they consistent with one another?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I don't -- I guess so. I don't think they contradict each other.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: All right. Thank you.All right. You were the breadwinner for your family, correct, your immediate family?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: And that included obviously for Maggie, correct?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I'm sorry.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: That included for Maggie, correct?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Absolutely.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: And in large measure for Buster and Paul as well, would you agree with that?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: That I was the breadwinner?

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: The primary breadwinner, yes.

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: No. I was their source of -- I was the source of income for Maggie, Buster and Paul.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Okay.

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I mean, as they got older -- I mean, there was some point where Buster had a job, but, I mean, I was still considering myself the provider for them at that time.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Again, I'm not -- there's no trick here. I'm just asking a simple question.

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Mr. Waters, I don't think that was a trick. So --

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: So, you were the primary breadwinner, we can agree on that?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Yes, sir.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Go ahead -- give me one second.I'm going to show you what's been marked state's 570 and see if you recognize this particular item. You can take it out of the bag.

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: All right, sir.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Do you know what that is?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Yes, sir.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: This is 571. MURDAUGH

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Then I'll show you what was in the bag of 570. Can you tell me what that is?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I can.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: What is it?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Which one?

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: 570, what is that?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: 571 is what I would consider to be my badge.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: All right. What is this one right here, 570?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: OK, 570 would be the one I told you about was my grandfather's badge after he retired when he became an assistant for my dad.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: I would offer 571 and 570 into evidence.

utterances.speaker: JUDGE
utterances.sentences: They're admitted.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Where did you keep 570, the one that was your grandfather's?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: It didn't have a single place that it was kept.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Do you know where it was recovered by law enforcement?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: No, sir.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Would you dispute if it was recovered out of the Mercedes you were driving September 4th, the day of the side of the road incident?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: No, I believe that.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Now the screen please. And 571, where did you keep this one?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Usually in my car.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Where in your car?

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: All right. When you had it in your dash, would you have it face up or face down?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I didn't have any particular manner in which I stored it anywhere. WATERSjury, how you had it on the dash?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: There may be occasions where I had it on the dash for some particular reason. There were a lot of times where it probably was in the dash for no particular reason other than that's where I put it. Just like, I put it on the seat or in the cup holder.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: All right. You said there were particular reasons why you might put it in the dash. What would those reasons be?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: It could be any number of things. If I'm going somewhere where I want somebody to see it, then I would put it in the dash. If there was another reason for somebody to see it, like, for instance, if I get pulled over, I might have it in the cup holder so an officer could see it when he walked up.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Why would you do that? Why would you put it in the cup holder? You're not saying you're on official business, are you?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: No, I'm not saying I'm on official business.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Why would you want it in a cup holder if you got pulled over?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Because I found that law enforcement oftentimes is friendlier when you're in law enforcement.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: When you're law enforcement? So you considered yourself law enforcement?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: No, sir, I can't say that I considered myself law enforcement.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: You carried a badge on you as an assistant solicitor for two decades roughly?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: From around '98, so yes, sir, two decades.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: And you would ride with it sometimes sitting in the front dash facing out, correct?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: That is correct.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: You would put it in the cup holder so that law enforcement would see you if you got pulled over, right?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: That's correct.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: OK, so you didn't consider yourself law enforcement?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I didn't consider myself to be law enforcement.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: You were using this badge to your advantage, taking license with it, is that correct?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I guess in some circumstances that is accurate. WATERSbetter treatment if you got pulled over?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Get better treatment if I got pulled over? I mean, that's probably a fair statement. Yeah, if somebody in law enforcement saw that, yeah, I would say that's true.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Did you have to take an oath when you got that badge?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: No, sir.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: You didn't?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Not that I remember. I don't -- I certainly don't recall taking one, like going somewhere and raising my hand.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Raising your hand and say I promise to do my duty fairly and with integrity, you never had to do that?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Mr. Waters, if I did I don't recall it. It was an informal process when I became a volunteer assistant solicitor for my dad. When I continued with Duffy, I mean, at some point -- you know, if I took any oath at all that I can remember, it would be on some paper that I may have had to sign, but I don't specifically remember doing that.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: All right. Let's talk about it. Let's go back to 571. On the inside of it what are those right there? Is that an ID card with your picture on it?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Yes, sir, that is.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: At the top, leave it there if you would please. Can you not see it?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I can. I was going to see what's on the back. All right, sir.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: It's got your picture on it. It got your name on it?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Yes, sir. That does have my picture and my name.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: All right. Put that one back for me please.

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: All right. You want to look at the top one?

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Look at the top one.

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: What office does it say you are on that top one right there, up at the top?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: State of South Carolina solicitor, the solicitor of the 14th Judicial Circuit.[16:15:03] It says as solicitor of the 14th Judicial Circuit, I do hereby certify that -- then it has --

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: It's your name.

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Right. It has all that data.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: What position does it say that you're appointed to?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: As the -- okay. It says that as solicitor of the 14th Judicial Circuit I do certify that Richard A. Murdaugh was on July 1st, 2013 appointed as the deputy solicitor of Allendale, Beaufort, Colleton, Hampton and Jasper counties. In and as authorized to enforce the laws in the 14 Judicial Circuit of South Carolina.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Also on the back.

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Yes, sir, signed by Duffie Stone.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Signed by Duffie Stone. So the deputy solicitor, is that correct?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I was never a deputy solicitor, Mr. Waters. That's what that says, but I've never been a deputy solicitor. I was a deputy solicitor -- I was a volunteer assistant solicitor. As far as I know Sean Thornton has been the only deputy solicitor that Duffie Stone had.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: And it's a simple point. It says deputy solicitor, but deputy solicitor is a higher rank than assistant solicitor, to your understanding?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: That's what I think. That was Sean Thornton. I've never been deputy solicitor even though it says that. I agree with -- that was signed by Duffie Stone, not by me.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: I understand. This is what was given to you.We went through this whole long thing at the beginning about whether you have an association with law enforcement community, but this was given to you not by your father but by a successor, correct?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: No, sir, I believe we got this because you were talking -- asking me if I took an oath. I don't remember taking an oath. You started to ask me about these things.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: OK, and you agree this card says deputy solicitor, right?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I agree that card says deputy solicitor.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Would you agree with me it says on the back that it is imposing special trust and confidence in your integrity? Is that what it says?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: If you're reading that off the back of it, I assume that it does. You were reading off the one that Duffie Stone gave me, correct?

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Yeah and the one at the top, where did that come from? Want me to bring it back to you?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: No, sir. I think I can see it.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: It's not focused well.

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: That's okay. I know what it is. I looked at it when you hand it to me.So, the card on the bottom is what I got from Duffie Stone. The one on the top -- the one on the top should give you a better -- there we go. All right. So the one on the top was what came from my dad when he was solicitor. The one on the bottom is what came from Duffie Stone when he was solicitor. Duffie Stone took over after my dad retired in 2006. Duffie Stone filled my dad's unexpired -- the rest of his unexpired four-year term like my dad filled my grand dad's and Duffie Stone became the solicitor.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Did you ever have lights in your vehicle?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: In the particular vehicle that --

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: No, in any vehicle.

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Yes, sir, I did.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Was that a government vehicle?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: No, sir, it was not.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: When did you have lights, blue lights and stuff?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Yes, sir, I had blue lights.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: When did you have blue lights? You did five cases over 20 years and you had blue lights in your private vehicle, correct?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: It was the vehicle I drove. It was the law firm's vehicle.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: The law firm's own vehicle. How did you get blue lights on that?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I had them installed.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Who installed them?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I believe that Eddie Gibson installed them.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Who is that?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: He's the guy who apparently does blue light work for most of the sheriffs departments in the 14th Circuit and a lot of police departments.

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I believe I had it in -- I believe I had blue lights in one vehicle.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: When did you have that installed do you think?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I'm not sure.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Five years, ten years?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: No, here, I can give you a timeframe.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Okay.

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: The vehicle that I was in -- that got taken in on June 7th, I got that vehicle sometime around late December or January. I had it for six months.I would have had the previous vehicle for five years. That's how long we kept vehicles in the law firm. So, I would have had it for five years. Sometime during that five-year period I had lights installed.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Did you ask the sheriff at the time if you could do that?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I did.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Who was that?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I believe it was T.C. Smalls. I believe in Colleton, it was Andy Strickland.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: In Colleton, it was Andy Strickland?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: And I believe in Allendale, it was Tom Carter.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Were you friends with Andy Strickland?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Yeah, I was friends with Andy Strickland.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: You said, hey, I'm going to get blue lights installed in my vehicle and he said, that's cool, or words to that effect?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I mean, that doesn't sound like the words he would have used or I would have used. But I certainly asked him and he certainly said it was okay.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: It was okay, all right.

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Along with Sheriff Smalls and I believe Sheriff Carter. I'm not positive about Sheriff Carter, but I believe so. WATERSSee if you recognize that.

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I believe this is my suburban. Yeah, this is my suburban that you all have.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: OK, is that where your badge was on the day of the incident?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I have no idea.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: You don't recall putting it there?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: No, but I don't take issue with the fact that it's -- I don't take issue with the fact that it's there if that's how they say it was. That's the picture.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Your honor, I would offer state's 507 into evidence.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: No objection.

utterances.speaker: JUDGE
utterances.sentences: It's admitted

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: You -- you testified some about the boat case. We'll talk more about that later.

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: The boat case being -- I'm sorry?

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: The boat wreck case, can we agree that's what we're talking about when we say the boat case, February of 2019?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Well, there's two things. You're referring to the civil case when you say the boat case. When I think the boat case, I think about the charges you all brought against Pau Pau.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: So, there's also the civil case.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: All right. Pau Pau, that was your nickname for Paul?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I mean, I called him Pau Pau. Look, Maggie called him Pau Pau. Buster calls him Pau Pau.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Sure.

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Roro calls him Pau Pau.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Roro? Who is Roro?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: That's Rogan Gibson.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: OK. And this jury, of course, has heard multiple recorded statements of you during the course of this. Did you ever refer to Paul as Pau Pau during that?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I don't know. WATERS

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: How I referred to -- I can say Paul if you prefer that.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: No, you can call him whatever you want. I'm asking you if you called him that during the course of that entire investigation or is the first time today publicly?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Is today the first time I called my son Paul Pau Pau? No, sir, that is not correct.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Have you ever called him that on all the recorded statements that this jury has heard?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I don't know.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Have you ever called Rogan Roro on recorded statements?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I called him Roro all the time.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: In the recorded statements did you call him that?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I don't know. I mean, I called him Rogan also, so I don't know. I'm happy to call him Rogan and I'm happy to call Paul Pau.

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Yes, sir.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Is that fair?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Yes, sir.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: All right. And we talked a little bit about your badge. Did you have your badge with you on the night of the boat wreck?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: On the night of the -- the night of the boat wreck did I have it with me?

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: When?

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Did you go to the hospital that night?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I did go to the hospital that night.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Did you have it with you then?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I don't know, but I don't believe so. I really don't know.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: You don't believe so?When you went to the hospital the night of the boat wreck, were you acting in any official capacity?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: The night of the -- when I went into the hospital was I in an official capacity?

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: No,

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: No, sir.(INAUDIBLE)

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: I'll show you what's been marked state's 569. Do you recognize the person on the right in that image?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: No, sir.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: You don't recognize that?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I don't think recognize him.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: I'm asking about -- MURDAUGH

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Is that you?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: It looks like me.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: What's hanging out of your pocket in plain view?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Looks like a badge.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: You didn't recall that until you that picture?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: No, sir, I did not.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Your Honor, offer state's 569 into evidence.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIIFED MALE
utterances.sentences: No objection.

utterances.speaker: JUDGE
utterances.sentences: Admitted.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: That's you in the white shirt, is that right?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Yes, sir, it is.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: This is the badge hanging out of your pocket. Do you remember which -- is that correct?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Looks to be, yes, sir.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Which badge is that? Which one of the two, do you remember?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: You can't tell from here.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: OK, why did you have it hanging out of your pocket like that? MURDAUGH

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: You don't remember that?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I don't remember that, no, sir.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Did you generally walk around with a badge hanging out of your pocket?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Generally speaking, no, sir, I did not.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Or only when you wanted some advantage from it?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Did I -- did I --

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Did you want some advantage wearing it like that?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Did I hang it out of my pocket when I wanted an advantage?

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I may have.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Okay.

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I certainly may have.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: What advantage did you want?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: When?

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Then.

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I don't even recall this, Mr. Waters. If I was wanting some advantage, as you say it, I guess -- I don't remember this. But I guess I would want -- you know, as I said, a badge has a warming effect with other law enforcement. If I was seeking any advantage, as you say, then I guess that would be what it was.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Did you ever want to be the solicitor?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: There was a time period where I did.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Did you ever want to be the solicitor? You'd like to be (ph) solicitor?(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: There was a time period when I absolutely did.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: When was that?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Prior to or around the time -- prior to my dad retiring.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Prior to 2006?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Yes, sir.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: How long did you explore that?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I mean, I really -- I wanted to be -- I wanted to be a solicitor for a long time, but, you know, at the time when my dad retired, I was already struggling with pills. I knew I couldn't do it.

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Yes, sir.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: We'll talk more about the pills. You were struggling with pills in 2006, correct?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: That's correct.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: But over that next 15 years, you still were able to maintain a lucrative law practice, would you agree with that?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Yes, sir.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: And you've already testified that all your law partners had no idea of this pill problem that you had all that time, correct?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I'm testifying that I believe -- in fact, I'm certain none of my partners knew I had an addiction.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: That night of the boat wreck, you say you don't remember putting your badge out, correct?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I don't even remember having my badge.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Do you remember going around talking to the kids, the other kids on the boat?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Yeah. I talked to some of them.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Do you remember going to do that?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Was your badge hanging out when you did that as well?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: You know, I would think so, Mr. Waters -- I don't think so.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: It just comes naturally to put your badge out for something like this and you don't remember?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I don't remember having my badge. I specifically know I didn't use the badge. Did I mean to do this? I'm not saying I didn't. I don't know if I was putting it in my pocket and the flap -- you noticed that the flap is not velcroed down. I don't know. I don't have a specific memory of that. I never went around, you know, acting like I was on official business.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: You're saying it might be an accident your badge was hanging out?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I'm saying I have no memory of that whatsoever.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: You never used these badges like a wallet, right?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: No, I did.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: You did?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I did.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: You're saying you had credit cards and stuff in there?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: No, sir. No, sir. I'm not saying that. I'm not saying on that night -- you asked me if I ever used it as a wallet. And there were times when I used it as a wallet.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Were you using it as a wallet that night?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I don't remember, but I don't think so. I didn't use it as a wallet often and I didn't use it for a wallet as very long.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: You would agree you had to make a conscious decision to grab that badge when you went into the hospital, correct? Would you agree with that?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Yeah, at some point I had to make a conscious decision to pick it up.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: But you're saying you don't know if you hung it out like that on purpose when you were talking to that officer or if it's just an accident it was hanging out of your pocket in full view of everyone?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Well, I am saying that because that is not how I would normally carry a badge. And even if I wanted to give somebody an impression, to me, that's got an obnoxious look to it. That's not something that -- I mean, it's not something I would typically do, but I may have done it that night. I have no memory of that.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Okay. All right. You're saying that could be an accident that it's hanging out like that?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I'm saying it could be or I could have put it there like that. I don't remember.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Did you generally walk around with it in your pocket? Would you only carry it when you wanted to use it for something?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I wouldn't generally carry it around in my pocket just any time.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Okay. All right. So, we got the badge that may be accidentally hanging out of your pocket. You won't concede you did that purposefully?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I mean, Mr. Waters, if you want me to say I did that on purpose, I don't have a problem with that. I'm saying I don't remember that. Can I tell you I did that on purpose? No, sir, I can't. Can I say this happened by accident? No, sir, I can't.What I can say is I don't remember it and that's not how I would normally -- it's not just how I would normally, you know -- it's just not something I did. That's not a normal thing. So I don't know. But --

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: All right. That's fine. You won't concede to this jury there wasn't any intention of you doing that at the hospital on the night of the boat wreck?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I'm saying I don't remember using that badge. I specifically remember -- you know, I'm sorry. Go ahead.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: You specifically remember what?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: When I went into the room with the kids, did I pull my badge out? I know I did not do that.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: No, because it was on your pocket like that, correct?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: It's on my pocket like that right then.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Did you use that to get into areas that shouldn't be accessed by nonofficial personnel?

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: While you were wearing the badge like that, did you tell any of the kids in the boat wreck not to cooperate with law enforcement.

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I never told anybody not to cooperate with law enforcement, whether I had a badge hanging out of my pants, didn't have a badge, any point in time did I tell anybody don't cooperate with law enforcement.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Did you become aware in March, or April, or May of '21 -- 2021, shortly before June, than an investigation into the investigation of that night had begun, as well as your conduct?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Yes, some. I did -- I did learn of that.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I don't know the status of that investigation being that I've been charged with so many things and haven't been charged with that, I'm assuming that there may not be charges.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Whether or not you were aware it had begun in the spring of 2021?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Yes, sir, I was aware -- well, at some point in time I became aware of it. Was it February, March, April? I know it was after -- I know it was after that night and it was before June 7th.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Before June 7th?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I'm pretty sure that I already -- I'm pretty sure I already knew that.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Did --

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: On June 7th.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: You mentioned Andy Strickland, do you know what happened to him?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Do I know what happened to him when?

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: How he lost his job as sheriff?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I believe that, when he was charged -- I can't -- I don't know if he resigned or he was suspended.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Okay. Do you remember if that was a few nights prior to you becoming aware of an investigation into the investigation of this boat case, including you?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Do I know what now?

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Andy Strickland was charged and lost his job, was that a few months prior to you becoming aware of the investigation into this incident that's on the screen?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: A few months prior?

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Uh-huh.

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I don't really know this for a fact, but I believe, as I'm sitting here today, I believe that Andy was charged back in the fall and, like I said, we learned about when -- I testified about when I understood there was an investigation into whether or not I was acting in a public manner or whatever, whatever it was you all were investigating, public corruption or that. So, if it was a couple months, if it was a month or two when AndyStrickland got charged, then -- I mean, if you showed me that, I would be surprised. I think he was charged before that.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: All right. This was a friend of yours, correct, a guy you asked if you could put lights in your car in a private vehicle, correct?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Well, I mean, Andy -- yeah, I considered Andy a friend. I considered T.C. a friend. I considered Tom Carter a friend. All of whom I asked if I could put lights in the vehicle.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: All right. And --

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: So, yes, sir, I mean, I considered Andy a friend.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Would you agree with me in at least the fall of 2020, your friend Andy Strickland was indicted and lost his job for a financial corruption investigation?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Objection, your honor. Relevance.

utterances.speaker: JUDGE
utterances.sentences: Response?

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Your Honor, I think there's a link between his knowledge of that and what he's admitted that there was an investigation going on in the months prior to the murders.

utterances.speaker: JUDGE
utterances.sentences: Sustain the objection.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: All right. We can at least agree you were aware prior to the murders there was this investigation, correct, the one on the screen? The one related to the boat -- the investigation into the boat case.

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Was I aware that y'all had started an investigation into what I did in the hospital prior to June the 7th?

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I believe that to be correct.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: All right.

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: If it wasn't before that, it was shortly after it.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: You testified that you've had a pill addiction for approximately 20 years, correct?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I think that's -- I think that's about right. WATERSlong did it take before you started doing that?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I'm not sure when the first time I did that is.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: You don't know?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: No, sir.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: You haven't gone back and thought about it?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Sure, I thought about it. You got to understand, I've been in rehab and jail. I don't have access to -- you know, all my telephone calls were put on the media. I haven't had a lot of phone access. I haven't had a lot of access. As we sit here today, I can't tell you the exact time. I don't deny I did it, but I can't tell you the time I first did it.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: You told the jury that's the cause of your financial problems?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Did I say that --

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Your opioid addiction was the cause of your financial problems?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: It was certainly a cause.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: A cause, not the only cause though, correct?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I wouldn't think it was the only cause, but, yeah, it was certainly a cause.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Do you recall testimony in this courtroom about how you had some land deals go bad around the time of the recession in 2008 and 2009?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Sure.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: You recall testimony from your law partners that you had some big cases that they thought cured those issues, correct?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I heard them say that, yes, sir.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Do you disagree with that?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Do I disagree with what they thought? No, I mean, I don't have any --

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Do you disagree with that was true?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: That they thought -- that my partners thought I had got past my financial difficulties? I have no reason to dispute that, Mr. Waters.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Was that true? Was what they thought true? MURDAUGHquestion?

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Yes, that's the question.

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Was it true I was past my financial difficulties? I mean, they were certainly better after that. But, I mean, no, I don't think I was past them, no, sir.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: What was the first big case after the recession that you had?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Mr. Waters, I can't tell you what the first big case was.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Do you remember the --

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: What date?

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Let's go with the Pinkney case, do you remember when that was?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I remember generally.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: What year was that? 2011, would you dispute that?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: 2011, when it ended?

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: When you got recoveries in that case?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I mean, if you're looking at something, that tells me that I have no reason to dispute that, but I can't remember off the top of my head, but that's certainly in the time frame.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Mr. Murdaugh, we'll go through it. Let's do it.

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Mr. Waters, like I said, I take you at that. I just don't know off the top of my head.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: All right.

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I don't have a reason to dispute that that.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: All right. I'll show you what's been admitted into evidence as state's 331. Let's go with actually 332, 333 and 334. Do you recognize those documents? Do you recognize this?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I do.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: What are those? They're disbursement sheets. Can I have them back please?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Just give me one second.

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Just trying to see which ones -- all right. There's some things about it that I'm curious about. But you ask your questions.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: We'll talk about that.All right. Let's talk about -- let's start with Natasha Thomas, do you remember her?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I do.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: How old was she when she became your client?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I'm not sure. She was young.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: She was a teenager?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I'm not sure. I know she was young.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: She was underage, correct?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Yes, she was underage, I do believe that. In fact, I know that.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Can you tell me what the -- she was injured in this wreck, in an automobile wreck, correct?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: And the company Michelin, that was one of the defendants for an alleged tire issue, is that correct?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: That is correct.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: All right. And do you remember how much Natasha Thomas got in that particular case? I can show it to you on 334. Do you remember how much you got?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: As a gross settlement, I believe she has $2 million.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: $2 million. How much were your or PMPD's fees that would be attributed to you in that -- out of that $2 million?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Yes, sir.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: All right.

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Excuse me.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Yes, sir. All right. That would be $800,000 in fees that were contributed to you. That has nothing to do with the money you subsequently stole from that teenager, correct?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: The $800,000 is different from money that I stole?

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: That's correct.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: All right. So, you got $800,000 attributed to you with the firm, but that was not enough. You also stole money from that teenager, is that correct?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: That is correct.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: All right. When you did that, did you sit down with her much as you sat down with this jury and explained to her what was going on while you were stealing her money?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: That would be the normal process, but I certainly don't remember specifically doing that.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: That would be the normal process, correct?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: It would be. May be a little different with a teenager, but certainly, I mean --

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: You would sit across the table and go through these documents, correct?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: If -- that would not be abnormal, yes, sir.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: All right. Then you would explain to them what was going on and how they were getting everything they were entitled to, correct?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: If I was the one doing it, yes, sir.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: You looked them in the eye while you were doing that, correct?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: It wouldn't be unusual for me to look them in the eye.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: While you were doing some fast talking to a teenager, correct?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I certainly was not telling her the truth. I don't know if I was talking fast or slow, but I wasn't telling the truth.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: All right. Well, you ultimately convinced her there was nothing amiss here, right, while you were stealing her money, correct?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I don't know if I convinced her nothing was amiss or if I misled her. I admit candidly in all of these cases, Mr. Waters, that I took money that was not mine and I shouldn't have done it.I hate the fact that I did it. I'm embarrassed by it. I'm embarrassed for my son. I'm embarrassed for my family. I don't dispute that I did it. I --

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: I understand that. You understand we have to ask about these things because we heard about it in a very academic paperwork manner. But every single one of these, you had to sit down and look somebody in the eye and convince them that you were on their side when you were not, correct? That's what you did in every single one of these.

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I mean, every time --

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Answer my question yes or no and then you can explain. I'll let you explain all day long.

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Well, I mean, no, sir. That may or may not be true. Mr. Waters, just try to get through this quicker, I admit --

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: I know you want to get through it quicker, but we're not. So, answer the question, please?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: What I admit is that I misled them, I did wrong and that I stole their money. Now, this is something -- what's the date on that one?

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: I'll bring it back to you.

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Well, you can tell me. I trust to tell you accurately.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: It's funny. Doesn't have a date on it. I'll let you take a look at it.

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I'm just looking at the date of the check. That's December 20th or 2011.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Okay.

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: And I admit that.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: All right.I know, Mr. Murdaugh, that you would like for it to be as simple as that, just to say, yes, ladies and gentlemen, I stole money and have that be the end of it. But in every single one of these cases --

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Objection to the comment, Your Honor.(INAUDIBLE)

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: -- like to just admit that and make this quick, correct? Isn't that what you said? Isn't that what you implied? MURDAUGHwife and my son, and I have sat here for all these weeks listening to all this financial stuff that I did wrong, that I'm embarrassed by. I'm happy to talk to you about as much of that as you want to talk about.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: We'll do that.

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I am required to talk about it as much as you want to talk about it, but the fact is, I cannot specifically remember sitting down the details that you're asking me for. I can't tell you. But what I can tell you is that in all these financial situations, I stole money that was not my money. I misled people that I should not have misled, and I did wrong.I can tell you that. And I may be able to tell you specifically, in some instances, what I did or did not do.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: All right. Well, good, well, we'll do that. But the point that I'm asking you is, it's not just as simple as some paperwork. You had to sit down and deal with these people, and convince them that you are telling them the truth, in order to steal this money, correct?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: That may not be true, because in some situations, I may not have had to do that. They may have just trusted me to do it.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Okay.

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: So, that's my point, is I misled them. There's no question about that. But did I sit down in each particular instance and, like, you are breaking it down step-by-step. I cannot say that. I can say I did wrong. I stole money that was not mine. And I should not have done it. And it was terrible, what I did.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: All right, well, let's look at states 330. This is Arthur Badger and the UPS case, correct?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: That's correct.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Do you remember what the total recovery was, in that particular case? There were multiple plaintiffs. Let me ask you that first. Multiple plaintiffs in the case, correct?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: That's correct.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: And do you remember what the total recovery was in that case?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Not exactly, but I mean, I know generally.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: All right. $12 million, would you disagree with that?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Was it $12 million? I mean, if you tell me it was $12 million, then I believe you. But I thought it was a little bit more than that.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: All right and an -- ultimately if you have multiple plaintiffs, how do you decide, as the plaintiffs order, how does it work out that the amounts of that total recovery get allocated to individual plaintiffs?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I mean, different cases and different ways.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Is it true that often, the defense attorneys or civil defense attorneys will ask the plaintiff's attorneys how you want that allocated?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Sometimes. Yeah.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Sometimes? Is that what happened in this case? In the Badger case?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I can't remember exactly how we came to that.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Who was the deep pocket in the Badger case? Do you remember? The defendant that had the money that you ultimately recovered from, the vast majority, do you remember?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Well, it was u.p.s. and I believe it was, I can't remember if it was corporate or if there was insurance, but it was certainly UPS that was a major defendant. But I believe Arthur Badger was the defendant. I can't remember. I know -- I know UPS was.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Did you sit down with him and explain this paperwork that you were using to steal his money?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I believe I did sit down with Arthur Badger.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: You managed to convince him that nothing was amiss and brought at the same time stealing money?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I believe I did.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: And did you allocate millions of dollars to Arthur Badger, personally, while only telling him that his recovery was going to be around $300,000?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I believe that I did, yes, sir.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: And on this exhibit 330, sat down and look him in the eye with all the stuff on here and fast talked him pass these figures, that he believed you and left thinking that you had on him right?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I would have -- I believe that I sat down with Arthur Badger and I know that I misled Arthur Badger, and I'm sure, at some point during that conversation, that I looked him in the eye.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Going back to states 333, remember, Hakeem Pinckney (ph), do you remember him?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I do.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: What happened to him?[16:5:04]

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: He was injured in the same wreck that Natasha Thomas was injured in.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Was he badly injured?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: He was.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: How badly injured was he?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Yes, I mean, he was terribly injured. He became a -- I can't remember what level, but he was a quadriplegic.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Do you remember what the total recovery amount was for him?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Not off the top of my head, no, sir.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: All right. Let me show you state's 333. And see what the total, if you recall what the total recovery was in that case.

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: It looks like it was $10,245,000.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: And that was for Hakeem, correct?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: That's correct.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: And how much of that was the attorney's fees that would have gone to PMPD that would have been attributable to you?

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: $4 million in legal fees that you would have gotten from this settlement. Is that correct?

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: And in the end, that wasn't enough for you, correct? Was that enough for you?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Was that enough for me in that case?

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I mean --

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Was 4 million -- over $4 million in legal fees that you received, that would have been attributable to you through the law firm at the end of the year, whatever it worked out to be, but you would have been credited with over 4 million in fees for that, is that correct?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: That's correct.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: And was that enough for you?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Was that enough for me? WATERS

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Oh, no, I took moneys from Hakeem Pinckney that did not belong to me that I should not have taken.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Been rendered a paraplegic.

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: No, sir. He was a quadriplegic.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Quadriplegic. Thank you for correcting me.

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Yes, sir.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Did you ultimately take money from his mother Pamela as well?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I believe that I did.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Do you remember how much money you took from Hakeem?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: No, sir. Not off the top of my head, I do not.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: If I told you it was over $370,000, would you agree with that?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: If that's what the records show, I don't dispute that.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Do you remember how much you took from the teenager Natasha Thomas in addition to your legal fees?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Not off the top of my head, no, sir.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: If I told you it was over $350,000, would you agree with that?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I don't dispute it.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Do you remember how much you took from Arthur Badger?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Mot off the top of my head, no, sir.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: If it was over $1.3 million, would you agree with that?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I don't dispute it.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Around the time that this was going on did you have some land deals that were going bad, that had gone bad?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Which --

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I think that they -- I think those had happened a little bit before that. But I had some land deals that certainly had problems.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: And that had something to do with the money you were taking as well, did it not?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I think the whole picture had things to do with me doing stuff I shouldn't have done. I mean, I would agree that -- that certainly would have played some role in it.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Were you living a wealthy lifestyle?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: A wealthy lifestyle?

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Mm-hmm.

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Probably. I mean, we were living whatever lifestyle -- probably.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Would you characterize your lifestyle as wealthy?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: You know, that's not -- that's not how I would characterize it.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: You wouldn't characterize it as wealthy?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I'm not going to take issue with it.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Okay.Around this time were you making more than a million dollars a year?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Around what time?
